column2: s the beginning of August which means.... this year&#39
column3: s Technic flagship is released. When I saw what this year&#39
column4: s set was, probably sometime back in March, I have to admit I wasn&#39
column5: t filled full of excitement. After the lovely surprise of the Cargo Plane, another construction vehicle. And one that we have a previous (reasonably recent) version of too, 8265.&nbsp
column6: And I will now have a hundred million yellow beams.&nbsp

column1: Still, sometimes looks can be deceiving, and as I have
column3: review about Technic flagships, I was pretty much always going to get this set. It&#39
column5: winced slightly as I parted with 170 pounds (OK, 161.50 with VIP discount) at the Discovery Store in Manchester on Saturday.&nbsp
column6: The pleasant shop assistant made me feel better though&nbsp
column11: I replied, smile included. There are few better arguments, it seems to me, for getting&nbsp
column12: an education and a good job&nbsp
column13: than being able to buy the biggest Lego sets....

column1: Anyway, sorry, let me tell you something about the set! In-keeping with the price, the box is big, much deeper than the usual boxes. When you open it of course it is not full, but there are lots of bags in there, some big tyres and that enormous bucket, which I think I read is the biggest element Technic has ever had. Wow, it is big - put it next to a minifigure!
column2: You also have a whole bunch of power functions stuff:&nbsp
column3: battery box
column10: three linear actuators. I dare say that those parts I just listed account for most of the cost of the set. You get tons&nbsp
column11: of yellow beams, surprisingly few gears, lots of axles, and the portal axle assemblies too.&nbsp

column3: font-size: 16px
column4: >At 1600-something pieces, this set is a lot&nbsp
column5: smaller in piece count than last year&#39
column6: s flagship, but when you have all the pieces out on your desk, you do still feel like you have bought a lot of pieces, and piece count isn&#39
column7: t everything anyway, as we all know.

column3: font-size: 16px

column1: There is also of course the sticker sheet, which I won'
column2: t use, as usual. The instruction book (yes, singular, book) is one of the ones with lots of pages and a spine - can&#39
column3: t remember the last time we got one of those, a welcome sight rather than the 3 or so thinner books we&#39
column4: ve had recently. And I really love that Lego now put the books in bags with a cardboard sheet. I used to despair at the book and sticker sheet being all mangled in the box! Thank heaven those days are over.

column2: s great. Not as long as some of the other flagship sets, but strangely I liked this. It&#39
column3: s still a good 4 or 5 hours including unboxing and everything. There are no really tricky bits, and no particularly complicated steps which I suppose is a shame. The build is also slightly weighted towards form rather than function, meaning that there are a lot of steps that make the model look nice as opposed to simply working. You can take that both ways though - sometimes it&#39
column4: s nice to put some effort into having it look right. It&#39
column5: s very satisfying seeing how the motors fit into the model - they&#39
column6: re not all mounted in the way you might expect, and there&#39
column7: s stuff too to get your head around that makes the model work. All the way through you are struck by how solid this model is - I guess it has to be to cope with the forces needed to move a good fraction of the weight of the model with the servo motor for steering. Probably it will be hard on the fingers to take to pieces but that&#39

column1: I like the green engine blocks - usually I find building the engine the worst bit of these models, but because of the new colour
column2: it seemed altogether new, like I hadn&#39
column3: t actually put one of these engines together a thousand times and could almost do it in my sleep
column4: ) I am also now pretty much convinced that Lego have tried hard to avoid being too tedious with symmetrical builds. This model has a few bits where you are building the &#39
column8: re repeating something. I like that a lot.&nbsp

column1: When you get it finished, you are struck by what a beast of a model this is. It'
column3: s really satisfying. Looking at it on my desk now, I&#39
column4: m happy I bought it. Last year&#39
column7: s is awesome in a slightly different way. It&#39
column8: s impressively solid. I love it. The wheels and bucket are massive. Did I say that already? Well, they are :)

column1: The remote control functions are great fun too - having two controls and the fact that the functions are arranged sensibly between them means that you can drive it properly, and when you want, operate the bucket properly, both functions at once. I spent a good while just doing n-point turns on my desk top and trying to scoop things up in the bucket.
Next to 8265 there is no contest - this thing is amazing. At some point I
column3: and put them side by side like I did with the Mobile Cranes, but I already know what the outcome will be. 42030 is awesome.

column1: I rated this set 4 overall even though while writing this review I felt like I wanted to give it 5. I think it'
column2: s expensive, but then you do get all the power functions stuff. There are no really new pieces, but then the exception&nbsp
column3: is the new massive bucket. It&#39
column4: s not the most complicated Technic model ever, nor is it particularly difficult or challenging to build, but then it is so heavy and big, and the remote functions and play value are excellent.&nbsp

,TRUE,5,4,4,5,5 asuss2812","2015-08-26T21:20:45.453Z","Need-to-have for every LEGO Technic fan","

I became owner of this set around 3 months ago, bought it as new. Volvo matches my collection of yellow building machines.
Box is big, although parts could be easily placed in smaller one, but it wouldn'
column2: t have made such impression. Instruction is stretched in one thick book.

column1: Of course, as a Technic model, none, but you can easily put it in driver cabin and it quite good fits.

A little bit challenging, not as much as 8110 or 42043, especially the 4-wheel-drive system, as the drive shaft is made of pretty much bricks. Handling the chassis while building was problematic, as the main joint was not stable (before mounting the actuator). I had the greatest satisfaction while putting completed engine to the body. I think it was the best part of the build.

It presents great in the showcase. Honestly, resemblance to real Volvo L350F is high. Playing is little bit hard, as the actuator works 0-1 way, so think about buying speed-control pilot after buying this set. The chassis aft should be stabilized. Also, the battery box has to be already connected with few bricks to be connected to rig, so putting it out is little bit painstaking.
ps. what a pity there is not central differential :(
All in all, it is great, licensed set which can give huge amount of joy to every lego fan. If you got few bucks - go and buy it!

,TRUE,4,5,5,4,4 pinz","2018-02-09T23:10:22.617Z","A great set","

The Volvo Wheel Loader is a great set, literaly. The wheels are the same size like those used in in the Unimog. It has quite some power (functions). Also there are nice details in the A-model.
To play with the set is fun, only the steering with the technic remotes is not realy
column2: finegraded, even if the servo would support it, but this a issue of the remote. You can use the big shovel like the real vehicle&nbsp
column3: would. And with the L-motor for the movement you have enough power to overcome even some obstacles.

column1: The building experience is nice, only the beams for the shovel need some care. the black angled technic beams are similar, so you have to be careful at assembling them. Overall you spend some enjoyable hours during you put together the pieces and see this massive beast grow and take shape.
The parts are clever used and the big black shovel is a really big and "
column3: part for a Lego set. The first time a actually&nbsp
column4: had it in hand was a real wow-moment.

column1: There are also a nice range of motors and 2 IR-remotes.
The B-model lacks a bit this love of details, the original truck for instance has 6 wheels, but in the set you have only 4, also the bed is a mere outline, like in the old days.
